ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Alkene synthesis, alkene additions, retrosynthesis, transition metal catalyzed reaction mechanisms
I learned about organic synthetic reaction. This half semester was largely focused on reactions with transition metal catalysts
synthetic methods
Organic strategy and fundamental understanding of mechanism

The various synthetic transformations available to organic chemists when trying to create complex molecules, as well as how to analyze complex molecules to determine potential synthetic pathways to achieve them.

I learned about the transformations of alkenes (hydrogenation, olefin metathesis, heck reaction), asymmetric formation of epoxides, cope and claisen rearrangements, and a couple more synthetic methods concepts. This class delved into the mechanisms and transition states of many reactions to provide a better theoretical understanding of common synthetic methods. I also learned about reaction conditions and the synthesis of special reagents necessary for commonly used reactions. This class was very informative and even though I am not a synthetic organic chemist I feel like I have a better understanding of what they do.
Many different reactions useful for organic synthesis
Gained insight on many named reactions. Lots of metal catalyze CH activation and CC coupling reactions.
I have learned a lot of the important considerations and distinctions to consider when making the same functional groups.
This course covered a variety of techniques of use in Organic Synthesis. The focus of this half-semester seemed to be on preparing and utilizing olefins, as well as various cross-coupling strategies.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Like the quarter before, this class is very well organized with neat and thorough notes and examples that add context. The psets align very well with the course material and reinforce the concepts and are an appropriate level of difficulty. Prof. Ellman is incredibly knowledgeable and has done a great job structuring the large amount of material in this class in a way that makes sense.
thoroughly enjoyed this course

The best strength of this course is that it is extraordinarily clear in its expectations.  I especially am a fan of the open-note exams, but also appreciate how the instructor went about designing the syllabus.  My main criticism of the course is its emphasis on reactions instead of on the chemistry that underlies them - while certain transition states were emphasized, the reasons for many regioselective and chiral outcomes were either not mentioned, or weren't necessary for performing well in the course.
Lectures were clearly presented and taught effectively! Class participation was limited, but was made up for by engaging content.

Strength: learned lots of different reactions I have never seen before. Weakness: sometimes I wish I could see how these reactions were actually developed, what insight their inventors had that allowed them to realize the reaction was possible.

This course was taught in a very organized way. Notes were clear and problem sets and tests drew from them. It sets you up to succeed and learn as long as you take good notes and review them well! Psets were worth 50% and the exam was worth 50%. You also get to drop a pset. Overall very well taught and very fair grading system.
It is very well organized
The course is well-organized and relevant, and the problem sets and exams accurately reflect the course content. No weaknesses of note.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you work in a synthetic organic chemistry lab, this is the best class you could possibly take to understand the reactions that you are likely carrying out. If you don't, this is still a great class just because of how well it is structured. The lectures are clear and interesting. The same is true of the psets, which are well-designed and help reinforce lecture concepts and prepare you for exams. The exam is open-note, which is very helpful in alleviating stress and allowing you to focus on concepts instead of memorization. I would recommend forming a study group to get the most out of the psets - the conversations about when to use what reagent can be quite interesting. Compared to last quarter, the class mostly stays the same but with more of an emphasis on transition metal mechanisms.
Yes, Ellman does a wonderful job teaching the class, and knowledge of the common organic reactions are helpful for chemists
yes if youre interested in synthesis
Yes. Great introduction to advanced organic chemistry.
Yes, I love synthetic organic chemistry and this was by far my favorite course I have taken.

YES THIS COURSE IS AMAZING! If you like organic chemistry in any capacity you'll love this course. I mainly study inorganic but even still I felt like I learned so much and there are so many resources available to learn from. It's super well organized and the grading is very fair. (50% pset, 50% exam, you can drop 1 pset, psets and exams are not easy but definitely not impossible)
I would recommend this course to anyone who took 432. It is a natural expansion of the knowledge you gained in that class and it teaches very relevant chemistry.
It is definitely an important course for any student with an interest in organic chemistry as it covers a broad range of important transformations
I would recommend without reservations. Certainly one of my favorite courses during my time at Yale so far.
